p.note: Reprinted in R. H. Stoddard's edition of Rufus M. Griswold's Poets and Poetry of America (New York: Hames Miller, 1873), 631. [Circulation]; "The poem may be read as a poem in search of itself; that is, as a poem in which the process of creation has been left visible. the first half of the poem experiments with the placement of the one-word refrain; the stanzas of the second half proceed with the stanza finally achieved." (Schurr 19) [Poetics]

body.p: When tempest winnowed grain from branWHEAT FROM BRAN [Denotation] Melville’s copy of Webster’s 1846 dictionary edition defines “bran” as “the outer coat of wheat, rye, or other farinaceous grain, separated from the flour by grinding” (Webster, An American Dictionary of the English Language, 1846). [Style--imagery] This appears to be an image of mass death. As the bran is winnowed (separated) from the grain, the body is separated from the soul. (Leslie McAbee), And men were looking for a man, Authority called you to the vanVAN [denotation] Melville’s copy of Webster’s 1846 dictionary includes definitions for “van” relevant to the first stanza. The foremost signification refers to “[t]he front of an army; or the front line or foremost division of a fleet, either in sailing or in battle.” The secondary definition presents a possible pun in keeping with the winnowing imagery of the first line: “Among farmers, a fan for winnowing grain” (Webster, An American Dictionary of the English Language, 1846). (Leslie McAbee), McClellan:AUTHORITY CALLED YOU TO THE VAN [Allusion—historical] McClellan was appointed commander of the Army of the Potomac after General Irvin McDowell faced defeat at the battle of the First Bull Run. Once General Winfield Scott retired in November 1861, McClellan then became the General-in-Chief of the Federal armies" (https://www.civilwar.org/learn/biographies/george-b-mcclellan). (Leslie McAbee)vanVAN [denotation] Melville’s copy of Webster’s 1846 dictionary includes definitions for “van” relevant to the first stanza. The foremost signification refers to “[t]he front of an army; or the front line or foremost division of a fleet, either in sailing or in battle.” The secondary definition presents a possible pun in keeping with the winnowing imagery of the first line: “Among farmers, a fan for winnowing grain” (Webster, An American Dictionary of the English Language, 1846). (Leslie McAbee), McClellan: Along the line the plauditPLAUDIT [Denotation] Meville’s copy of Webster’s 1846 dictionary defines “plaudit” as “applause; praise bestowed” (Webster, An American Dictionary of the English Language, 616). (Leslie McAbee) ranAllusion—historical] As a new commander, McClellan gained the respect and admiration of Union troops, “instilling in them a remarkable (esprit de corps)” (https://www.civilwar.org/learn/biographies/george-b-mcclellan). (Leslie McAbee), As later when Antietam's cheers began.[Criticism] In her article “Correspondent Lines,” Eliza Richards interprets the “univocality” of both spectators (those “[a]long the line” of newspaper reports) and soldiers (who later shout “Antietam’s cheers” along the line of battle) as “eerily mindless.” Richards adds that the “authority" that promotes McClellan is "probably not the will of the people [...] since ‘Antietam’s cheers’ preceded or accompanied a slaughter—not to mention that McClellan lost his command soon after the battle …” (156). (Leslie McAbee)

Through storm-cloud and eclipse must move Each Cause and Man, dear to the stars and Jove; Nor always can the wisest tell Deferred fulfillment from the hopeless knell— The straggler from the floundering ne'er-do-well. A pall-cloth on the Seven Days fell, McClellan— Unprosperously heroical! Who could Antietam's wreath[allusion][interpretation] The wreath here refers both to the figurative wreath that would crown the victor, as well as the many wreaths laid to commemorate the fallen. (Eric Meckley) foretell?
Authority called you; then, in mist And loom of jeopardy—dismissed.AUTHORITY CALLED YOU…DISMISSED [Allusion—historical] Due to Lincoln’s eagerness to mount an offensive against Lee’s army and McClellan’s hesitancy, the latter was removed as General-in-Chief in the spring of 1862, though he still retained command of the Potomac Army. Soon after, McClellan led the army in the Peninsula Campaign to take Richmond. After the bloody Seven Day’s battles that ended the Peninsula Campaign without the capture of Richmond, Lincoln relieved McClellan of his command, appointing Henry Halleck as General-in-Chief of the army and General John Pope as commander of the Army of the Potomac (Biography: George B. McClellan, https://www.civilwar.org/learn/biographies/george-b-mcclellan). Leslie McAbee But staring peril soon appalled; You, the Discarded, she recalled— Recalled you, nor endured delay; And forth you rode upon a blasted way, ArrayedARRAYED [Denotation] Melville’s copy of Webster’s 1846 dictionary defines “arrayed” as follows: “Set in order, or in lines; arranged in order for attack or defense; dressed; adorned by dress; impanneled” (An American Dictionary of the English Language). [Intratextuality] Hennig Cohen notes that Melville elsewhere enlists a variation of “array” in the Battle-Pieces poem “Lee in the Capitol” (line 37) : “Of Pope’s impelled retreat in disarray” (234). (Leslie McAbee) Pope's rout, and routed Lee's array, McClellanYOU, THE DISCARDED…ENDURED DELAY [Allusion—historical] Lincoln reinstated McClellan as commander after John Pope failed to take Richmond in the battle of Second Manassas. McClellan moved the Union army to rout Lee’s march on Maryland in 1862 (Biography: George B. McClellan, https://www.civilwar.org/learn/biographies/george-b-mcclellan). (Leslie McAbee): Your tent was choked with captured flags that day[allusion][historical][interpretation] Although Melville emphasizes the flags captured and brought to McClellan, the Union and Confederate forces suffered comparable losses in the battle. (jpulz@unc.edu / Eric Meckley), McClellan. Antietam was a telling frayFRAY [Style—pun] While the primary signification of “fray” here means “[a] combat, a battle,” it also connotes the wearing of fabric, which may be significant to the image of “captured flags” two lines above. (Leslie McAbee)ANTIETAM WAS A TELLING FRAY [Allusion—historical] McClellan’s maneuvers to rebuff Lee’s advance in Maryland culminated in the battle of Antietam, also known as the Battle of Sharpsburg, on September 17, 1862, known as the single bloodiest day of the war (Biography: George B. McClellan, https://www.civilwar.org/learn/biographies/george-b-mcclellan). (Leslie McAbee).

Recalled you; and she heard your drum Advancing through the ghastly gloom. You manned the wall, you propped the Dome, You stormed the powerful stormer home, McClellan: Antietam's cannon long shall boom.

At Alexandria, left alone, McClellan— Your veterans sent from you, and thrown To fields and fortunes all unknown—AT ALEXANDRIA...ALL UNKNOWN [Allusion--historical] Following the Peninsula Campaign, in which he failed to capture Richmond, McClellan withdrew his men to Aquia Creek, VA and Alexandira, VA. Most of McClellan's men were reassigned to John Pope in August of 1862 after McClellan was relieved of duty as commander of the Army of the Potomac (blueandgraytrail.com). (Leslie McAbee) What thoughts were yours, revealed to none,

While faithful still you labored on— Hearing the far Manassas gun!HEARING THE FAR MANASSAS GUN [Allusion--historical] After McClellan's command was given to Major General John Pope, the latter met a withering defeat at the Battle of Second Manassas in August of 1862. McClellan was subsequently reinstated as commander of the Army of the Potomac ("Biography: George McClellan, https://www.civilwar.org/learn/biographies/george-b-mcclellan). (Leslie McAbee) McClellan, Only Antietam could atone.

Your medalled soldiers love you well, McClellan: Name your name, their true hearts swell; With you they shook dread Stonewall's spellWITH YOU THEY SHOOK DREAD STONEWALL'S SPELL [Allusion—historical] Before the Battle of Malvern Hill, the final clash of the Seven Days Battles and the Peninsula Campaign, McClellan seized a strategic position at Glendale, which the Federal army needed to advance to the James river. Lee sent several divisions, including Major General Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson to attack the Union’s Glendale position, which was located between Malvern Hill and White Oak Swamp. Federal artillery prevented Jackson’s advance through White Oak Swamp (“The Seven Days Battles,” https://www.civilwar.org/learn/articles/seven-days-battles) (Leslie McAbee), With you they braved the blended yell Of rebel and maligner fell; With you in shame or fame they dwell, McClellan: Antietam-braves a brave can tell[allusion][literary][intratextual] Here Melville uses the trope of native American warrior "braves" to symbolize the commonality between those who fought at Antietam. This also appears in "Apathy and Enthusiasm," "Donelson," and "Running the Batteries," among others. (Eric Meckley).

And when your comrades (now so few, McClellan— Such ravage in deep files they rue)AND WHEN YOUR COMRADES … DEEP FILES THEY RUE) [Critical] Eliza Richards suggests that the last stanza reflects a change in the “line” of support for McClellan mentioned in the first stanza. In the last stanza, McClellan’s support has dwindled as many of the soldiers who loved him have died in battle. Richards reads “deep files” as an image that “evokes both trenches dug as mass graves and swathes of men cut down by mechanized weapons in rows running perpendicular to advancing battle lines” (“Correspondent Lines” 157). (Leslie McAbee) Meet round the board, and sadly view The empty places; tribute due They render to the dead—and you! Absent and silent o'er the blue; The one-armed lift the wine to you, McClellan[Critical] [Poetics—lineation] Eliza Richards argues that the poem’s broken lines, cut short to shout “McClellan” in a “one-beat line,” create a visual impression of newspaper and poetry print “full of white spaces and gaps that cannot be closed.” Richards reads this discontinuity in the poem’s lineation as “an analogy to looking around the table and seeing the permanent gaps in a once seemingly solid and infinite black line of force” (“Correspondent Lines” 158). (Leslie McAbee), And great Antietam's cheers renew.
